citation.article-title: Numerical taxonomic study of fast-growing soybean rhizobia and a proposal that Rhizobium fredii be assigned to Sinorhizobium gen. nov.

p.s: Description of Sinorhizobium gen. nov.
Sinorhizobium(Si.no.rhi.zóbium. L. n. sinae, China; Gr. n. rhiza, root; Gr. n. bios, life; M. L. neut. n. Sinorhizobium, rhizobia isolated from roots in China)
Rods 0.5 to 0.9 by 1.2 to 3.0 μm, usually containing granules of poly-β-hydroxybutyrate.
Nonsporeforming.
Gram negative.
Motile by means of one polar flagellum or one to more than three peritrichous flagella.
Aerobic, possessing a respiratory type of metabolism with oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor.
Colonies are circular, convex, semitranslucent, raised, and mucilaginous, usually 2 to 4 mm in diameter within 3 to 5 days of YMA.
Pronounced turbidity develops after 2 to 3 days in agitated broth.
The optimum temperature is 25 to 30°C, but most strains grow at 35°C and some strains grow at 10°C.
Optimum pH, 6 to 8.
Some strains grow at pH 5.0, and other strains grow at pH 10.5.
Most strains grow in the presence of 1.0% NaCl, but not
1.5% NaCl, although a few strains grow well on YMA containing 4.5% NaCl.

D-Arabinose, cellobiose, fructose, D-galactose, glucose, L-glutamine, lactose, D-mannose, mannitol, D-ribose, sodium succinate, xylose, and D-turanose are utilized as sole carbon sources, but ammonium tartrate, ammonium oxalate, cellulose, dulcitol, fucose, glycine, sorbose, sodium algniate, and vanillic acid are not.
All strains produce acid on YMA.
Ammonium chloride and nitrates rather than amino acids are the preferred sole nitrogen sources, but some strains utilize certain amino acids.
Peptone is poorly utilized.
All strains require pantothenate and nicotinic acid, but their reactions to other vitamins are variable.

All strains are susceptible to doxycycline (1 μg/ml), tetracycline (1 μg/ml), aureomycin (1 μg/ml), terramycin (1 μg/ml), and streptomycin (125 μg/ml), but resistant to vancomycin (5 μg/ml), chloromphenicol (5 μg/ml), erythromycin (25 μg/ml), penicillin (5 μg/ml), medemycin (125 μg/ml), amophotericin B (125 μg/ml), and kanamycin (1 μg/ml).

Reactions to pesticides are variable, but all strains are susceptible to 38.08% dimetheate (250X), 50% phoxin (250X) and 40% omthoate (500X) , as well as to 0.01% potassium tellurite and calcium hypochlorite (2%).
All strains produce cytochrome oxidase and catalase.

The members of this genus do not exhibit a wide host range, but effectively nodulate Glycine soja, Glycine max cv. TGm119, G. max cv. TGm120, G. max cv. TGm344, G. max cv. Kai-Yu No. 8, Vigna unquiculata cv. VITA-3, and Cajanus cajan cv. CITA-1.
An ineffective symbiosis is formed on Vigna radiata, Macroptilium atropurpureum, Macroptilium lathyroides, and Sesbania cannabina (2, 19,

Large plasmids have been demonstrated in most strains, and the structural nifgenes are contained on large plasmids (the only known exception is strain USDA 194) (9). nif genes and nod genes are located on a single plasmid (1).
The G+C content of the DNA ranges from 59.9 to 63.8 mol%.
